content.description: More steep climbing on the ocean-side of the cliff.

Another area classic!  Steep, exposed climbing above the water.

There are actually 2 (or more) variations.  The plumb line climbs pockets up a steep face to the right-hand side of a small roof that caps the route (5.10c).  Another variation steps left at a large ledge mid-height and climbs a shallow corner before traversing back right beneath the summit cap (5.10a/b).
content.location: Around to the right of the Main Face, overlooking the ocean.

content.description: Use the middle anchors. Start as if going up to the roof, but instead stay to the right. Use a small crack and good feet up to a large jug (watch out for sharp point at bottom of jug). Crux is about 2/3's the way up at some bad holds, get past for slightly easier climbing to the anchors.
content.location: left or right of the column of rock, beginning doesn't matter so much as its all 5.easy climbing for first 1/3 of route

content.description: Classic Point Dume edge-pulling at an accessible grade.  Be creative, the easiest line meanders quite a bit.
content.protection:
Bolted top-anchor.  Use long anchor cord.

Lead bolts are push-button compression bolts and insufficient for lead climbing.

content.description: Climb straight up to where your rope meets the edge near the top to avoid swinging and possibly tearing into your rope or even cutting your rope! The crux is about 3/4 up on a small ledge near the right side of the face . It’s a long reach to a huge grab.  2nd crux is getting over the edge about 10 ft from the top.
content.protection: For this route you must tie off of a boulder at the top. There is one place to tie off. . I’d recommend bringing a mat for where the rope drags over the edge. I use two 30ft pieces of 8mm cord.
content.location: At the top of point dume your tying off of the only rock you potential can, you can’t miss it.  It’s the farthest most point from the directly opposing main wall anchors. The east most south facing wall.

content.description: Follow picture - start on tiny crack, follow up and right. Finish is same place as South Face Right.
content.location: Ocean facing wall, in between South Face Right and South Face Center Right.

content.description:
Start at the base of the flake all the way to the left where the beach meets the hillside.  Follow the flake up and to the right until it ends.  The crux is the last move on the flake, maybe 5.8.  Then traverse right  for a few feet and follow the regular Left Route up to the two anchor bolts below the big ledge just below the top. Then traverse right on friction and crimps just below the ledge until you are underneath the toprope anchor.  Then up and over the ledge to the top!

5.9 variation: instead of traversing right after the flake head straight up until you hit the ledge.  This way doesn't see much traffic and is a little mossy and/or sandy.
content.protection: Top rope above the Center/Left Routes.  If you want you can run it through the anchor bolts above the Left route to reduce the pendulum if you fall, but it's not really that bad because of the positive slope of the cliff--if you do fall off it's pretty easy to stop yourself from swinging.
content.location: On the far left of the beach side cliff.

content.description: Slightly easier than the left-most route.
content.protection:
Bolted top-anchor.  Use long anchor cord.

Lead bolts are push-button compression bolts and insufficient for lead climbing.

content.description: The hardest of the low-angle routes on the west-facing wall.
content.protection:
Bolted top-anchor.  Use long anchor cord.

A directional is required to safely top rope this route from the anchors atop the cliff.

The lead bolts are currently missing.

content.description: Very easy "problem". Slightly overhung with large if sharp pockets/jugs. Do it barefoot just for fun cause you're on the beach.
content.location: On the northern corner of the northernmost of the large boulders which sit west of the main cliff.

content.description: This route follows sustained thin crimps up a slight depression in the center of the west-facing wall.  Perhaps the best of the low-angle face-climbs at Point Dume.
content.protection:
Bolted top-anchor.  Use long anchor cord.

Lead bolts are push-button compression bolts and insufficient for lead climbing.

content.description: About 5.5 up most of the steep corner that leads up to the small roof. Getting over the roof is 5.7 or so. Avoid using the rusty pipe for anchoring. Walk off via same descent trail down to the beach.
content.protection: Long slings for TR anchor, plus optional stopper.
content.location:
This is on the backside that actually faces south.  Just a few steps around the corner to the right of the SW side with the Oceanside routes that face the ocean.  This backside faces the small beach area behind the main cliff. Rock seemed fairly solid, but sure, possible choss, so easy on the pulls. Done only because the easy Face routes were swarmed by high tide. Seriously, water swept all the way up that side of the beach. It happens.

This is the prominent corner system just to the left of the start for Rhein-Dance.

content.description: The true standout at the cliff!  Sustained for the grade and truly aesthetic!!
content.protection:
Bolted top-anchor.  Use long anchor cord.

Directionals are required to safely top rope this route from the anchors atop the cliff.

Lead bolts are push-button compression bolts and insufficient for lead climbing.
